meta.content: Front Page; New York and Region
meta.name: online_sections

block.p: Ex-Captives Are Home; U.S. Sees No Openings The 15 Britons held captive in Iran arrived home to feelings of relief and questions about how they behaved. Toughening, Prime Minister Tony Blair spoke of possible links between Iran and terrorism in Iraq. Washington said it saw no new openings in dealing with Tehran.
PAGE A10

$4.5 Billion Bid for Chrysler Kirk Kerkorian, the billionaire investor, just can't break his Chrysler habit. After failing in one takeover in the 1990s, he has returned with a $4.5 billion bid for the struggling automaker.
BUSINESS DAY, PAGE C1
A Battle Between Sweeteners Fighting for market dominance, two makers of artificial sweeteners, Equal and Splenda, go to court over the meaning of the phrase ''made from sugar.''
BUSINESS DAY, PAGE C1
Spending Money to Make It Instead of tapping his own money directly, Mitt Romney has embarked on an effort to leverage his personal fortune into donations to his Republican primary campaign.
PAGE A17
Dazzling Debut for Pitcher The Japanese star Daisuke Matsuzaka struck out 10 in his first major league start as Boston defeated Kansas City, 4-1.
SPORTSFRIDAY, PAGE D1
Go Ahead, Make It a Double ''Grindhouse, '' made up of a film by Robert Rodriguez and one by Quentin Tarantino, is a tribute to the spirit of trash cinema. A review by A. O. Scott.
WEEKEND, PAGE E1

Toughening, Prime Minister Tony Blair spoke of possible links between Iran and terrorism in Iraq. Washington said it saw no new openings in dealing with Tehran.
